Laying a Foundation for Energy Abundance








Bedrock Materials develops and produces active materials for sodium-ion batteries, a low-cost and earth-abundant alternative to lithium-ion batteries.













Why Sodium Ion?



























Sodium-Ion Batteries are the Backbone of the New Energy Economy






Unlike modern lithium-ion batteries which rely on critical minerals like nickel, cobalt, lithium, and copper, sodium-ion batteries rely largely on manganese, iron, sodium, and aluminum. The extraordinary abundance of these materials eliminates price volatility and supply chain insecurity.


























Megatons of Electrode Materials are Needed to Meet Global Demand









Sodium-ion batteries can be manufactured using the same equipment and infrastructure as lithium-ion batteries, but the engineered active materials they require are not yet produced at scale. That's where we come in.
Bedrock Materials designs, engineers, and manufactures sodium-ion cathode materials based on earth abundant metals. We specifically tailor our materials to meet the needs of underserved applications in mobility markets, such as low-voltage, starter-lighting-ignition, micromobility propulsion, and industrial traction.
As an North American supplier, we also help battery makers take advantage of tax credits such as those found in the Inflation Reduction Act.




















Why Sodium-Ion Today?






Sodium-ion batteries deliver somewhat less energy density than lithium-ion, but recent advancements have finally made them competitive for entry-level markets.




















Vehicle Efficiency






Today’s electric vehicles travel 35% further on the same energy as vehicles from 12 years ago.


















Fast Charging






Charging is three times faster and 10 times more ubiquitous than ten years ago, reducing range requirements


















Battery Packaging






Modern battery packs use space 50% more efficiently, improving pack-level energy density regardless of chemistry choice




















Technology Designed for the Mass Market






Sodium-ion batteries are a natural fit for segments of the market where cost, abundance, and safety are prioritized over premium performance.














Dependent on critical minerals

Lithium
Copper
Nickel
Cobalt
Phosphorous
Graphite












Premium energy density (500 Wh/L+)



























Few or no critical minerals

Iron
Manganese
Sodium
Aluminum
Carbon












Mass market energy density (300 Wh/L+)




















Bottom-up Disruption






Today's best sodium-ion batteries can nearly match the energy density of LFP. As they increase in cycle life, their utility will expand to increasingly lifetime sensitive applications.

Bedrock Materials Accepted into StartX





PALO ALTO , Calif., April 3, 2024 – Bedrock Materials, Inc. (“Bedrock Materials”), a leading innovator in the production of sodium-ion battery active materials, today announced that it has been accepted into the prestigious StartX incubator, a startup incubator designed to support new ventures built by Stanford students, professors and alumni.
Rafael Vila, CTO of Bedrock Materials and former StartX Student in Residence commented, “We couldn’t be happier to officially join this community of Stanford builders and innovators. As we grow to build a national champion for the production of battery materials, we look forward to working with StartX to remain deeply rooted in the Stanford community which gave birth to our company.”
StartX represents over 1600 founders which have generated over $40 billion in combined valuation and 18 companies valued over $1 billion. Over the 10-year history of StartX, 93% of its venture backed companies are still growing or acquired. 
—-
Contact Information: hello@bedrock.inc

Bedrock Materials Announces Award of $150,000 CalSEED Grant





PALO ALTO, Calif., September 13, 2023 — Bedrock Materials, Inc. (“Bedrock”), a leading innovator in the production of sodium-ion battery materials, announced that it has been selected to receive a grant of $150,000 under the California Sustainable Energy Entrepreneur Development (CalSEED) program. The company was among 27 companies selected from 153 applicants.
Commenting on the development, CTO Rafael Vila said, “We’re proud to work with the CalSEED team and the Energy Commission to demonstrate sodium-ion battery technology that we believe can benefit ratepayers in the storage and use of sustainable energy. We look forward to deploying these funds to create jobs and develop technology in the State of California.”
In total, $4 million of CalSEED funds will be deployed into clean energy innovations throughout California.
CalSEED is funded by the California Energy Commission’s EPIC (Electric Program Investment Charge) program, which awards $120M annually for clean technologies that benefit California ratepayers. It is administered by New Energy Nexus, the world’s leading ecosystem of funds and accelerators that support diverse clean energy entrepreneurship.
